front: What are the most frequent causes of Peripheral Neuropathy?
back: The most common cause is diabetes, followed by alcoholism, autoimmune diseases, vitamin deficiencies, and tumors.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBELLUM

front: What symptoms are typically associated with Peripheral Neuropathy?
back: Symptoms include severe pain, paraesthesia (tingling/numbness), loss of coordination, muscle paralysis, and autonomic dysfunction.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBELLUM

front: What are the clinical features of Peripheral Motor Neuron Syndrome?
back: It presents with limited motor deficits, muscle hypotonia, fasciculations, muscle atrophy, and hyporeflexia or areflexia.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBELLUM

front: From which primary germ layer does the entire nervous system develop?
back: The ectoderm.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBELLUM

front: What is the function of the notochord during embryonic development?
back: It induces the overlying ectoderm to become neuroectoderm, forming the neural plate and starting neurulation.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBELLUM

front: When do the cranial and caudal neuropores close during neural tube formation?
back: The cranial neuropore closes around day 25-26, and the caudal neuropore closes around day 27-28.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBELLUM

front: What key peripheral nervous system structures are derived from the neural crest?
back: Neural crest cells form sensory ganglia, Schwann cells, melanocytes, adrenal medulla cells, and enteric neurons.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBELLUM

front: What are the three primary brain vesicles formed during development?
back: The Prosencephalon (forebrain), Mesencephalon (midbrain), and Rhombencephalon (hindbrain).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBELLUM

front: Into what structures does the Prosencephalon divide during secondary vesicle formation?
back: It divides into the Telencephalon (cerebral hemispheres) and the Diencephalon.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBELLUM

front: What are the main structural components of the Central Nervous System (CNS) and Peripheral Nervous System (PNS)?
back: The CNS consists of the brain (diencephalon, cerebellum, brainstem) and spinal cord, while the PNS includes 12 pairs of cranial nerves, 31 pairs of spinal nerves, and ganglia.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: What is the functional difference between the Somatic and Vegetative (Autonomic) nervous systems?
back: The Somatic system controls conscious activity and striated muscles for external interaction, while the Vegetative system regulates unconscious internal organs, vessels, and glands via smooth and cardiac muscle.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: What are the three primary morphological parts of a neuron and their functions?
back: The cell body (soma) contains the nucleus and metabolic machinery, dendrites receive information from other neurons, and the axon conducts electrical impulses away from the cell body.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: According to morphology, how are pseudounipolar, bipolar, and multipolar neurons classified?
back: Pseudounipolar neurons have a single T-shaped process (sensory ganglia), bipolar neurons have two processes at opposite poles (retina), and multipolar neurons possess multiple dendrites and one axon (majority of CNS).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: Which glial cells are responsible for myelination in the Central Nervous System versus the Peripheral Nervous System?
back: In the CNS, oligodendrocytes provide myelin sheaths for axons, while in the PNS, Schwann cells (neurolemmocytes) secrete the myelin sheath.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: What are the specific roles of astrocytes and microglia in the Central Nervous System?
back: Astrocytes form the blood-brain barrier and provide metabolic support to neurons, whereas microglia act as macrophages to phagocytose debris and mediate immune responses.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: How do A-type, B-type, and C-type nerve fibers differ in structure and conduction speed?
back: A-type fibers are myelinated with fast conduction (somatic/motor), B-type are lightly myelinated with medium speed (preganglionic autonomic), and C-type are unmyelinated with slow conduction (postganglionic autonomic/pain).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: What are the primary functions of the neurotransmitters GABA and Glutamate?
back: GABA is the major inhibitory neurotransmitter that blocks signal transmission, while Glutamate is the primary excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: What are the five essential components of a reflex arc?
back: The components are the receptor, sensory (afferent) neuron, integration center (CNS), motor (efferent) neuron, and effector (muscle or gland).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: How do unconditioned (innate) reflexes differ from conditioned (acquired) reflexes?
back: Unconditioned reflexes are genetically programmed, permanent, and subcortical, while conditioned reflexes are learned, temporary, and involve the cerebral cortex.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: What are the three classifications of receptors based on their location and the origin of the stimulus?
back: Exteroceptors respond to external stimuli (skin), proprioceptors detect body position and movement (muscles/joints), and interoceptors monitor internal visceral stimuli.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: In the general scheme of ascending sensory pathways, what are the functions of the first, second, and third order neurons?
back: The first neuron (protoneuron) carries impulses from receptors to the CNS, the second neuron (deutoneuron) relays signals within the spinal cord or brainstem, and the third neuron (tritoneuron) projects from the thalamus to the sensory cortex.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: What are the key pathological features of Multiple Sclerosis (MS)?
back: MS is characterized by focal demyelination and axonal degeneration in multiple locations, likely caused by an autoimmune reaction destroying myelin.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: What are the primary clinical symptoms of Multiple Sclerosis?
back: Symptoms include double vision, vision loss, balance disorders, ataxia, and sensory deficits due to impaired impulse transmission.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: What is the most common cause of peripheral neuropathy?
back: Diabetes (diabetic neuropathy) is the most frequent cause, though alcoholism, autoimmune diseases, and vitamin deficiencies are also known etiologies.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: Where do symptoms of peripheral neuropathy typically manifest?
back: Symptoms usually trigger in the hands and feet and include pain, paraesthesia, loss of coordination, and vegetative manifestations.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: What defines a lesion in Peripheral Motor Neuron Syndrome?
back: The lesion affects the peripheral motor neuron (spinal or cranial nerves) up to the neuromuscular junction, causing flaccid paralysis.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: What are the specific signs of Peripheral Motor Neuron Syndrome?
back: Signs include fasciculations, muscle atrophy, hypotonia, hyporeflexia or areflexia, and motor deficits limited to specific territories.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: From which embryonic layer does the entire nervous system originate?
back: The entire nervous system develops from the ectoderm, specifically induced to become neuroectoderm during neurulation.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: What is the function of the notochord during nervous system development?
back: The notochord induces the overlying ectoderm to form the neural plate, marking the beginning of neurulation.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: When do the neuropores close during the formation of the neural tube?
back: The cranial neuropore closes around day 25-26, while the caudal neuropore closes around day 27-28.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: What major peripheral structures are derived from the neural crest cells?
back: Neural crest cells give rise to sensory ganglia, Schwann cells, adrenal medulla cells, and meninges (pia and arachnoid).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: What are the three primary brain vesicles formed during early development?
back: The primary vesicles are the Prosencephalon (forebrain), Mesencephalon (midbrain), and Rhombencephalon (hindbrain).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::DIENCEPHALON

front: What are the two main divisions of the Nervous System?
back: The Central Nervous System (CNS), consisting of the brain and spinal cord, and the Peripheral Nervous System (PNS), consisting of nerves and ganglia.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What distinguishes the Somatic Nervous System from the Vegetative Nervous System regarding control and effectors?
back: The Somatic system controls conscious relations with the external environment via striated muscle, while the Vegetative system controls unconscious internal organ activity via smooth muscle, cardiac muscle, and glands.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the primary morphological difference between pseudounipolar, bipolar, and multipolar neurons?
back: Pseudounipolar neurons have one T-shaped extension (sensory), bipolar have two extensions at opposite poles (retina/ear), and multipolar have several dendrites and one axon (majority of CNS).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the functional difference between Golgi Type I and Golgi Type II neurons?
back: Golgi Type I are projection neurons with long axons forming nerve tracts, while Golgi Type II are intrinsic interneurons with short axons and inhibitory roles.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: How does the myelination process differ between the Central Nervous System and the Peripheral Nervous System?
back: In the CNS, myelin is secreted by oligodendrocytes, whereas in the PNS, it is synthesized by Schwann cells.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the characteristics and primary functions of A-alpha, A-beta, and C-type nerve fibers?
back: A-alpha are large, fast motor/sensory fibers; A-beta are medium-fast touch fibers; C-type are small, unmyelinated, slow fibers for pain and autonomic functions.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the specific roles of astrocytes, microglia, and ependymal cells within the CNS?
back: Astrocytes form the blood-brain barrier and support neurons; microglia act as macrophages for immune defense; ependymal cells line ventricles and secrete CSF.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the difference between chemical and electrical synapses in terms of transmission speed and mechanism?
back: Chemical synapses use neurotransmitters across a synaptic cleft for slower, modifiable transmission, while electrical synapses use gap junctions for very fast, bidirectional transmission.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: How do asymmetric (Type 1) and symmetric (Type 2) synapses differ in structure and general function?
back: Asymmetric synapses have a thicker postsynaptic membrane and are usually excitatory, while symmetric synapses have membranes of equal thickness and are usually inhibitory.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the primary excitatory and inhibitory neurotransmitters in the nervous system?
back: Glutamate is the major excitatory neurotransmitter used widely in encephalic synapses, while GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) is the major inhibitor acting via negative feedback.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the difference between unconditioned and conditioned reflexes?
back: Unconditioned reflexes are innate, genetic responses (e.g., sneezing), while conditioned reflexes are acquired, learned responses involving the cerebral cortex.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: How do exteroceptors, proprioceptors, and interoceptors differ based on location?
back: Exteroceptors are in skin/sense organs (external stimuli), proprioceptors are in musculoskeletal system (body position), and interoceptors are in viscera/vessels (internal stimuli).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: In the general scheme of ascending sensory pathways, where are the first, second, and third neurons located?
back: The first neuron is in sensory ganglia, the second neuron is in the posterior horn of the spinal cord or brainstem, and the third neuron is in the thalamus projecting to the cortex.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the specific stimuli detected by mechanoreceptors, photoreceptors, and nociceptors?
back: Mechanoreceptors respond to mechanical pressure/vibration, photoreceptors react to light, and nociceptors react to stimuli causing tissue destruction (pain).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What characterizes the pathology of Multiple Sclerosis (MS)?
back: MS is an autoimmune disease characterized by focal demyelination and axonal degeneration, which disrupts impulse transmission.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the three main categories of causes for Peripheral Neuropathy?
back: Common causes include diabetes (most frequent), alcoholism, autoimmune diseases, vitamin deficiencies, and tumors.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What clinical signs distinguish Peripheral Motor Neuron Syndrome?
back: It features hypotonia, fasciculations, muscle atrophy, and hyporeflexia or areflexia limited to specific nerve territories.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: From which embryonic layer does the nervous system originate?
back: The entire nervous system develops from the ectoderm.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What structure induces the overlying ectoderm to form the neural plate?
back: The notochord induces the ectoderm to become neuroectoderm and form the neural plate.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: During neurulation, when do the cranial and caudal neuropores close?
back: The cranial neuropore closes around day 25-26, and the caudal neuropore closes around day 27-28.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are four major structures derived from the neural crest cells?
back: Neural crest cells give rise to sensory ganglia, Schwann cells, melanocytes, and adrenal medulla chromaffin cells.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the names of the three primary brain vesicles?
back: The primary vesicles are the Prosencephalon, Mesencephalon, and Rhombencephalon.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Into which secondary vesicles does the Prosencephalon divide?
back: The Prosencephalon divides into the Telencephalon (cerebral hemispheres) and the Diencephalon.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the three flexures that develop in the neural tube?
back: The neural tube develops the mesencephalic, cervical, and pontine flexures.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: How do the functional roles of the basal and alar plates differ?
back: The basal plate is motor in function, while the alar plate is sensory.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: At which vertebral level does the adult spinal cord terminate?
back: The spinal cord ends at the level of L2 vertebra, forming the conus medullaris.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: From which embryonic structure does the cerebellum develop?
back: The cerebellum develops from the rhombic lips of the metencephalon (dorsal hindbrain).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the function of the corpus callosum?
back: The corpus callosum is a commissural tract that connects the two cerebral hemispheres.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the primary defect in Anencephaly?
back: Anencephaly results from the failure of the cephalic neuropore to close, resulting in absent brain and skull.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What distinguishes a meningocele from a meningomyelocele?
back: A meningocele involves the bulging of meninges through a vertebral defect, whereas a meningomyelocele includes parts of the spinal cord within the sac and presents with neurological symptoms.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the anatomical definition of Chiari Malformation Type I?
back: It is characterized by herniation of the cerebellar tonsils more than 3 mm below the foramen magnum.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What specific anomalies are associated with Chiari Malformation Type II (Arnold-Chiari)?
back: It involves large displacement of the cerebellar vermis, clivus hypoplasia, and is frequently accompanied by lumbosacral myelomeningocele.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the two layers that compose the cranial dura mater?
back: The external periosteal layer (adherent to the skull) and the internal meningeal layer (avascular mesothelium).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the function of the tentorium cerebelli?
back: It separates the posterior cranial fossa containing the cerebellum from the occipital lobes, dividing the cranial cavity into supratentorial and infratentorial spaces.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which dural septum projects into the longitudinal fissure between the cerebral hemispheres?
back: The falx cerebri.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the clinical significance of the lumbar cistern?
back: It extends from the conus medullaris to the S2 vertebral level and serves as the primary location for lumbar puncture to collect CSF.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the role of arachnoid granulations?
back: They are protrusions of the arachnoid membrane through the dura that allow CSF to drain into the venous sinuses.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the function of the dentate ligaments?
back: They are fibrous strips of the spinal pia mater that anchor the spinal cord to the dura, providing stability within the vertebral canal.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What characterizes a typical extradural (epidural) hematoma?
back: It is a biconvex collection of blood between the skull and dura, typically caused by rupture of the middle meningeal artery.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: When is the glymphatic waste clearance system most active?
back: The system is most active during sleep, facilitating the clearance of waste products from the brain parenchyma.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the underlying cause of the Lissencephaly-Pachygyria spectrum?
back: These anomalies are caused by a defect in neuronal migration occurring between 12 and 24 weeks of gestation.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What defines spina bifida occulta?
back: It is the simplest form of spina bifida involving failure of posterior vertebral arch fusion, often covered by skin and usually asymptomatic.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What space lies between the meningeal layer of the dura and the arachnoid mater?
back: The subdural space.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which subarachnoid cistern is located between the medulla oblongata and the cerebellum?
back: The cerebellomedullary cistern (cisterna magna).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the anatomical boundaries of the spinal cord?
back: The spinal cord extends from the foramen magnum at the level of the pyramidal decussation down to the lower border of the L2 vertebra.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the two enlargements (intumescences) of the spinal cord and their functional significance?
back: The cervical intumescence (C4-T1) corresponds to the origin of the brachial plexus, while the lumbar intumescence (L1-S3) corresponds to the origin of the lumbar plexus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the composition and attachment of the filum terminale?
back: The filum terminale consists of an internal pial portion descending through the lumbar cistern and an external dural portion that anchors to the base of the coccyx.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What structure is formed by the nerve roots descending below the conus medullaris?
back: The filum terminale and the lumbar and sacral nerve roots form the cauda equina.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: According to Chipault's formula, how does the spinal cord segment (neuromere) correspond to the vertebra in the upper thoracic region?
back: In the upper thoracic region (T1-T5), the neuromere is located two vertebrae above the corresponding vertebral body (n + 2).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the origin and vascular territory of the anterior spinal artery?
back: The anterior spinal artery arises from the vertebral arteries, courses along the anterior median fissure, and supplies the anterior 2/3 of the spinal cord.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the clinical significance of the artery of Adamkiewicz?
back: Also known as the great anterior radiculomedullary artery, it is the dominant supply to the lower spinal cord, typically arising between T9 and L2 on the left side.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the functional difference between the white and grey communicating branches (rami communicantes)?
back: The white communicating branch contains myelinated preganglionic sympathetic fibers, while the grey communicating branch contains unmyelinated postganglionic sympathetic fibers.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the function of the Renshaw circuit in the spinal cord?
back: Renshaw cells provide negative feedback inhibition to alpha motoneurons via inhibitory synapses to limit motor discharge and ensure movement accuracy.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the mechanism of the inverse stretch reflex mediated by Golgi tendon organs?
back: When tendons stretch, Ib sensory fibers activate inhibitory interneurons that inhibit the alpha motoneurons of the agonist muscle, preventing motor over-reaction and potential damage.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What types of neurons are located in the dorsal (posterior), ventral (anterior), and lateral horns of the spinal cord?
back: The dorsal horn contains sensory neurons, the ventral horn contains somatomotor neurons, and the lateral horn contains visceromotor neurons.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which Rexed laminae are primarily concerned with exteroceptive sensation?
back: Laminae I to IV, located in the dorsal horn, are primarily concerned with exteroceptive sensation.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which Rexed laminae comprise the ventral horn and contain motor neurons?
back: Laminae VIII and IX comprise the ventral horn and contain mainly motor neurons that innervate skeletal muscle.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What functional nuclei or structures correspond to Rexed laminae VII and X?
back: Lamina VII corresponds to the intermediolateral (sympathetic) and sacral parasympathetic nuclei; Lamina X corresponds to the central gelatinous (periependymal) matter.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the three general types of nerve fibres found in the spinal cord white matter?
back: They are long ascending fibres (to brain), long descending fibres (from brain), and short interconnecting fibres (propriospinal).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the origin and sensory function of the Lateral spinothalamic fasciculus?
back: Originating from the nucleus proprius, it conducts impulses for pain and temperature sensibility.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: How do the Direct (Posterior) and Indirect (Anterior) spinocerebellar tracts differ regarding decussation and body region?
back: Direct (Flechsig) is ipsilateral and serves the lower body; Indirect (Gowers) decussates twice and serves the upper body.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the anatomical and functional difference between the Goll (Gracile) and Burdach (Cuneate) fasciculi?
back: Goll is medial and carries fine touch/vibration from the lower body; Burdach is lateral and carries the same information from the upper body.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the role of the Spinoreticular fasciculus (SR)?
back: It acts as a secondary pathway for exteroceptive impulses to the cortex, maintaining "cortical alert" via the ARAS.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the pathway differences between the lateral and anterior pyramidal (corticospinal) fasciculi?
back: Lateral (75-80%) decussates at the pyramidal decussation; Anterior (20-25%) descends ipsilaterally then decussates in the anterior white commissure.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the origins and functions of the Rubrospinal and Tectospinal tracts?
back: Rubrospinal originates from the red nucleus and controls muscle tone; Tectospinal originates from the tectal nuclei and coordinates head/trunk reflexes to visual stimuli.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the functional contrast between the Lateral and Medial Reticulospinal fasciculi?
back: Lateral (bulbar) inhibits reflex motility and muscle tone; Medial (pontine) stimulates reflex motility and muscle tone.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What characterizes Brown-Sequard Syndrome?
back: It involves hemisection of the spinal cord, causing ipsilateral loss of motor function and proprioception with contralateral loss of pain and temperature.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What specific deficits define Anterior Spinal Syndrome?
back: It involves damage to the anterior 2/3 of the cord, causing bilateral loss of motor function, crude touch, and pain/temperature sensation below the lesion.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What structures are visible on the anterior surface of the Medulla Oblongata?
back: The anterior surface features the anterior median fissure, the bulbar pyramids, and the olive delimited by pre- and retro-olivary sulci.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What anatomical landmark marks the downward apex of the fourth ventricle?
back: The calamus scriptorius, named for its resemblance to a writing quill-nib.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the dual function of the area postrema located at the caudal end of the fourth ventricle?
back: It serves as a chemoreceptor for blood and a transducer of stimuli into neural signals.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What structure creates the facial colliculus on the floor of the fourth ventricle?
back: Fibers from the motor nucleus of the facial nerve as they loop over the abducens nucleus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What unique characteristic distinguishes the origin of the trochlear nerve (IV) from other cranial nerves?
back: It is the only cranial nerve to emerge from the posterior surface of the brainstem.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What arteries supply the lateral part of the medulla oblongata?
back: The vertebral arteries caudally and the postero-inferior cerebellar arteries cranially.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which vessels supply the paramedian part of the pons?
back: The paramedian pontine arteries, which are branches of the basilar artery.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What vascular supply serves the paramedian part of the midbrain, including the oculomotor and red nuclei?
back: The peduncular paramedian arteries, which are branches of the posterior cerebral arteries.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: How are the somatomotor nuclei arranged in the brainstem?
back: They form a paramedian column (somitic) for eye and tongue muscles and a lateral column (branchial) for muscles of facial expression, mastication, and pharynx/larynx.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the path of fibers from the facial motor nucleus before they exit the brainstem?
back: They course dorsomedially to loop around the abducens nucleus (forming the facial colliculus) and then direct ventrally.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which parasympathetic nucleus provides control over the parotid gland?
back: The inferior salivatory nucleus, whose fibers synapse in the otic ganglion.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the targets of the parasympathetic fibers originating from the lacrimo-muco-nasal nucleus?
back: The lacrimal glands, nasal mucosa, and palatine glands via the pterygopalatine ganglion.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What specific ocular function is controlled by the accessory oculomotor nucleus (Edinger-Westphal)?
back: Accommodation (near reflex) and miosis (pupil constriction).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Where is the apparent origin of the trigeminal nerve (V) located on the anterior surface of the pons?
back: The motor component is located medial to the sensitive component.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the anatomical significance of the medullary striae on the posterior surface of the brainstem?
back: They are transverse fascicles extending from the median sulcus to the inferior cerebellar peduncle, arising from the arcuate nuclei.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What separates the hypoglossal trigone from the vagal trigone in the fourth ventricle?
back: There is no specific sulcus named between them, but they are adjacent structures; the funiculus separans separates the vagal trigone from the area postrema.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the afferent sources for the miosis reflex and the near (accommodation) reflex?
back: Miosis reflex afferences come from the retina via the pretectal area, while the near reflex afferences come from the visual area via the superior quadrigeminal colliculi.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Where do the preganglionic parasympathetic fibers of the oculomotor nerve (III) synapse?
back: They synapse in the ciliary ganglion, which is attached to the ophthalmic nerve in the orbit.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the anatomical shape and extent of the solitary nucleus?
back: It is a Y-shaped structure extending from the inferior border of the facial colliculus to the pyramidal decussation, located in the dorsolateral medulla and lower pons.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which cranial nerves provide taste (gustatory) afferents to the solitary nucleus and from which regions?
back: VII bis carries taste from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue, IX from the posterior 1/3, and X from the epiglottis.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the main visceral afferent sources to the caudal part of the solitary nucleus?
back: General visceral afferents from chemoreceptors and mechanoreceptors in the heart, lungs, airways, and gastrointestinal system via nerves IX and X.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What makes the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve unique among CNS sensory nuclei?
back: It is the only sensory nucleus containing first-order afferent neurons (pseudounipolar), rather than second-order neurons.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What specific reflex is mediated by the mesencephalic nucleus projecting to the motor trigeminal nucleus?
back: It mediates the jaw jerk reflex, which is a monosynaptic reflex.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What type of sensory information is primarily processed by the spinal (medullary) nucleus of the trigeminal nerve?
back: It is a synaptic station for pain and temperature sensation from the face, sinus cavities, and oral structures.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What type of sensory information is primarily processed by the main (pontine) sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve?
back: It processes discriminative touch sensation from the face and conscious proprioception of the jaw.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: How are vestibular inputs from the semicircular canals and otolith organs distributed to the vestibular nuclei?
back: The medial and superior nuclei receive input from semicircular canals, while the lateral and inferior nuclei receive input from the utricle and saccule.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the functional difference between the medial and lateral vestibulo-spinal tracts?
back: The medial tract projects to upper thoracic levels to control head position, while the lateral tract projects the entire cord length to control body posture.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the distinct pathways and functions of the efferents from the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei?
back: The dorsal nucleus projects via the lateral lemniscus for a fast warning pathway, while the ventral nucleus projects to the superior olivary complex for sound localization.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the specific function of the von Monakow (accessory cuneate) nucleus?
back: It carries unconscious proprioception from the shoulder region and base of the neck to the cerebellum via the cuneocerebellar tract.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the anatomical characteristic of the primary inferior olivary nucleus and the destination of its axons?
back: It has a crenated C-shape and sends axons (climbing fibers) to the contralateral cerebellum via the inferior cerebellar peduncle.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the primary neurotransmitter of the locus coeruleus and its physiological role?
back: It is the main source of norepinephrine in the brain, involved in the physiological response to stress and panic.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the functional differences between the pars compacta and pars reticulata of the substantia nigra?
back: Pars compacta contains dopaminergic neurons for fine movement control, while pars reticulata contains GABAergic neurons that serve as the output center of the basal ganglia.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the two anatomical parts of the Red Nucleus?
back: The caudal magnocellular (paleorubrum) part and the rostral parvocellular (neorubrum) part.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the primary function of the Red Nucleus?
back: It inhibits muscle tone and coordinates the synergy and automatism of movements.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What receptors are found in high density within the Periaqueductal Grey (PAG)?
back: Vasopressin and oxytocin receptors.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the primary roles of the Periaqueductal Grey (PAG)?
back: Activating defensive reactions, modulating pain impulses, and triggering maternal feelings.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the main afferent pathway to the Inferior Colliculus?
back: The lateral lemniscus (bilaterally), where most lemniscal fibres synapse.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: How do the superficial and deep layers of the Superior Colliculus differ functionally?
back: Superficial layers respond almost exclusively to visual stimuli from the retina, while deep layers respond to other or multiple modalities.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the primary efferent target of the Pretectal Area regarding eye control?
back: The Edinger-Westphal nucleus, which mediates the pupillary light reflex (miosis) and accommodation reflex.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the primary neurotransmitter of the Raphe nuclei?
back: Serotonin, which plays an important role in mood regulation, arousal, and sleep installation.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the function of the Ascending Reticular Activating System (ARAS)?
back: It increases the general level of sensory stimulation to raise the cortical stimulation and neural activity (level of consciousness).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the difference in origin between the Descending Reticular Inhibiting System (DRIS) and the Facilitating System (DRFS)?
back: DRIS originates in the pontine reticular nuclei, while DRFS originates in the bulbar (gigantocellular) nuclei.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the specific role of the Kolliker-Fuse nucleus within the Parabrachial area?
back: It is part of the pneumotaxic center responsible for regulating respiratory rate.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What sensory modalities are carried by the Medial Lemniscus?
back: Discriminative touch, vibration, and conscious proprioception for the trunk, neck, and limbs.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What anatomical event is known as the 'sensory decussation'?
back: The crossing over of internal arcuate fibres in the medulla to form the medial lemniscus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What percentage of fibres in the Pyramidal fasciculus decussate at the lower limit of the medulla?
back: Approximately 80% cross to form the crossed pyramidal fasciculus, while 20% descend as the direct pyramidal fasciculus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which cranial nerve motor nuclei receive only contralateral innervation from the Cortico-bulbar fasciculus?
back: The upper motor neurons of the Facial nucleus (lower quadrant) and the Hypoglossal nucleus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Where does the Rubro-spinal fasciculus originate and how does it decussate?
back: It originates in the paleorubrum (magnocellular red nucleus) and decussates via Forell's decussation.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the origins and fiber types of the Anterior and Lateral Reticulo-spinal fasciculi?
back: The Anterior fasciculus originates in the pontine reticular nuclei with mostly direct fibres, while the Lateral fasciculus originates in the giant cell nucleus with mostly crossed fibres.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What reflex is mediated by fibres connecting the trapezoidal body to the masticatory (V<sub>3</sub>) and facial (VII) nuclei?
back: These fibres mediate the reflex contraction of the tensor tympani and stapedius muscles in response to acoustic stimuli.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the pathway and function of the tecto-nuclear fibres within the Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus (MLF)?
back: These descending fibres connect the quadrigeminal colliculi with cranial nerves III, IV, VI, and XI to mediate oculo-visual and acustico-visual reflexes.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the primary functional role of the Posterior Longitudinal Fasciculus Schütz (PLF)?
back: The PLF provides connections for vegetative reflexes, including ascending viscero-sensory pathways to the hypothalamus and descending pathways from the hypothalamus to visceromotor nuclei.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is Duret haemorrhage and what causes it?
back: It is a haemorrhage in the midbrain and upper part of the pons caused by a traumatic descending movement of the brainstem.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the characteristic neuropathological features of Parkinson's Disease?
back: It is characterized by a decrease in dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra (pars compacta) and the presence of Lewy bodies.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the primary symptoms of Ponto-cerebellous Angle Syndrome?
back: Symptoms include peripheral facial hemiparesis, facial hypoesthesia, hearing loss, tinnitus, vertigo, and motor control disorders due to compression of facial and acoustic-vestibular nerves.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What sensory deficits are present in Wallenberg syndrome (lateral medullary ischemia)?
back: It causes ipsilateral facial pain and loss of contralateral pain and temperature sensitivity on the body.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What structures are vascularized by the Antero-inferior Cerebellar Artery (AICA)?
back: AICA supplies the middle cerebellar peduncles, the antero-inferior cerebellum (flocculus), and the dorso-lateral segment of the pons containing the facial and cochlear nerve nuclei.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the two types of inhibitory interneurons found in the molecular layer of the cerebellar cortex?
back: They are stellate cells (neurotransmitter: taurine) and basket cells (neurotransmitter: GABA), both synapsing onto Purkinje cells.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: How do granule cells contribute to signal processing in the cerebellum?
back: Granule cells send parallel fibres into the molecular layer, which bifurcate and form excitatory synapses with the dendrites of Purkinje cells.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the origin and synaptic pattern of climbing fibres within the cerebellum?
back: Climbing fibres originate from the contralateral inferior olive and provide strong, direct input to Purkinje cells, making numerous synaptic contacts from a single fibre onto a single cell.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the anatomical description and functional classification of the Dentate nucleus?
back: The Dentate nucleus is the largest nucleus, located in the white matter of the hemispheres, has a folded shape like the lower olive, and is classified as neocerebellar.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the vascular territory of the Postero-inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA)?
back: PICA supplies the inferior cerebellar peduncles, the inferior vermis, the inferior hemispheres, and the dorso-lateral medulla (including vestibular nuclei).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the ascending and descending origins of the Central Tegmental Fasciculus?
back: Ascending fibres originate in the raphe nuclei (part of ARAS), while descending fibres originate in the thalamus, subthalamic region, striated bodies, and red nucleus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the functional role of the paleocerebellum (spinocerebellum)?
back: It controls muscle tone for the trunk and limbs via unconscious proprioception, primarily comprising the vermis and paravermian zones.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the major afferent and efferent connections of the neocerebellum?
back: Afferents arrive via the cortico-ponto-cerebellar pathway, while efferents project from the dentate nucleus to the thalamus and cortex to regulate voluntary movement.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the primary functions of the middle cerebellar peduncle?
back: It acts as the major route for ponto-cerebellar fibers, transmitting information from the cerebral cortex to the cerebellum.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the main efferent tracts found in the superior cerebellar peduncle?
back: It contains the dento-rubric and dento-thalamic fasciculi, which connect the cerebellum to the red nucleus and thalamus respectively.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the clinical features of neocerebellar syndrome?
back: It is characterized by intentional tremor, adiadocokinesia, dysmetria, and incoordination of fine movements due to lateral hemisphere lesions.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What characterizes the cognitive-affective cerebellar syndrome?
back: It involves deficits in executive, visual-spatial, and linguistic skills alongside depression, resulting from lesions in the lateral or posterior cerebellar hemispheres.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the primary function of the Ventral Posterior Lateral (VPL) thalamic nucleus?
back: It serves as the main relay station for somatosensory pathways (medial lemniscus and spinothalamic) from the body to the primary sensory cortex.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the primary function of the Ventral Posterior Medial (VPM) thalamic nucleus?
back: It acts as a relay station for face somatosensory information (trigeminal lemniscus) and gustatory fibers to the sensory cortex.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which arteries provide the primary vascularization to the thalamus?
back: The thalamus is supplied mainly by branches of the posterior cerebral artery (thalamogeniculate and paramedian arteries) and the posterior communicating artery.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the hormonal function of the pineal gland?
back: It synthesizes melatonin to modulate sleep patterns, along with serotonin and norepinephrine.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the anatomical location and role of the subthalamic nucleus (Luys nucleus)?
back: Located in the subthalamus, it regulates motor activity through reciprocal connections with the basal nuclei (globus pallidus).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What arteries provide the primary blood supply to the optic chiasm, tuber cinereum, and pituitary gland?
back: The pituitary arteries, which are branches of the internal carotid artery (specifically the upper and inferior pituitary arteries).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What divides the hypothalamus into lateral and medial hypothalamic areas?
back: The anterior columns of fornix and the mammillo-thalamic fasciculus divide the hypothalamus into these two distinct regions.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the primary function of the suprachiasmatic nucleus?
back: It serves as the center for circadian rhythm, receiving direct afferences from the retina and indirect ones from the lateral geniculate bodies.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which hypothalamic nuclei are considered the center for thermoregulation and sexual behavior?
back: The preoptic nuclei and anterior nucleus function as thermoregulation centers responsible for sexual behavior.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the functional difference between the dorsomedial and ventromedial nuclei of the tuberal region?
back: The dorsomedial nucleus is the center of hunger, whereas the ventromedial nucleus is the center of satiety.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the primary function of the posterior nucleus in the mammillary region of the hypothalamus?
back: The posterior nucleus acts as the center of thermogenesis and represents the central segment of the sympathetic system.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: How does the hypothalamo-pituitary portal system regulate the adenohypophysis?
back: It transports hormones secreted by hypothalamic neurons to the anterior pituitary gland to control its secretion via negative feedback.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What characterizes Dejerine-Roussy thalamic painful syndrome?
back: It is a condition following thalamic stroke where paralysis is replaced by burning, stinging sensations, and hypersensitivity (allodynia).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What specific hypothalamic lesion causes Non-24-hour sleep-wake syndrome?
back: Lesions of the suprachiasmatic nucleus alter the sleep-wake rhythm, causing it to prolong beyond the normal 24 hours.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the functional differences between the left and right cerebral hemispheres?
back: The left hemisphere dominates speech, language, and logic, while the right hemisphere handles non-verbal skills like object recognition.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What anatomical structure is located deep within the fissure of Sylvius (lateral sulcus)?
back: The lobe of Insula is found deep within the lateral sulcus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What sulcus separates the parietal lobe from the occipital lobe on the medial surface?
back: The parieto-occipital fissure separates these lobes on the medial surface.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the three parts of the inferior frontal gyrus divided by the fissure of Sylvius?
back: The inferior frontal gyrus is divided into the orbital, triangular, and opercular parts.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What gyrus is located between the central fissure of Rolando and the postcentral sulcus?
back: The postcentral gyrus (parietally ascending) is located in this position.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the anatomical location of the cuneus gyrus?
back: The cuneus gyrus is located on the medial surface of the occipital lobe, delimited between the calcarine sulcus and the parieto-occipital sulcus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the two main phylogenetic subdivisions of the pallium (cerebral cortex)?
back: The archipallium (old cortex) and the neopallium (new cortex).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the cytoarchitectonic difference between allocortex and isocortex?
back: Allocortex has neurons placed in 2 or 3 layers, whereas isocortex has neurons placed in 6 layers.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the two structural types of archipallium found in the brain?
back: Archicortex (two layers or diffuse) and paleocortex (three layers with olfactory function).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which layer of the neocortex contains Betz cells and is responsible for motor outputs?
back: The Internal pyramidal layer (Layer V), which contains large pyramidal neurons and sends efferences to motor pathways.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which layer of the neocortex receives afferences from subcortical structures and sensory pathways?
back: The Internal granular layer (Layer IV).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What distinguishes a granular heterotypic isocortex from a pyramidal heterotypic isocortex?
back: In granular heterotypic isocortex, the granular layers predominate, while in pyramidal heterotypic isocortex, the pyramidal layers predominate.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the anatomical location of the external Baillarger stria?
back: It is located in the inner granular layer (Layer IV).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the two main structural groups of the archicortex?
back: Structures of the dorsal hippocampus (e.g., Indusium griseum) and structures of the ventral hippocampus (e.g., Hippocampus proper, Dentate gyrus).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the pathway of Papez's memory circuit?
back: Hippocampus → fornix → mammillary bodies → mamillary-thalamic fasciculus → anterior thalamic nucleus → cingulum → entorhinal cortex → hippocampus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the primary function of the amygdaloid nucleus?
back: It is responsible for identifying danger and feelings of fear, as well as modulating love, affection, and general mood.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: How does the function of the Primary Motor Area differ from the Premotor Area?
back: The Primary Motor Area controls the execution of voluntary movements, while the Premotor Area is responsible for preparation, spatial guidance, and systematization of movements.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the specific function of the Additional Motor Area (AMA)?
back: It intervenes in the planning of complex movements and the coordination of bilateral movements.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the function of Brodmann Area 8 (Frontal Eye Field)?
back: It controls voluntary movements of the eyeballs and rapid eye movements (jerks) for visual attention.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the functional roles of the anterior and posterior parts of Broca's Area (BA 44/45)?
back: The anterior part deals with semantics (meaning), while the posterior part deals with phonology (sounds of language).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the functions of the visual association areas V4 and V5?
back: V4 is necessary for colour recognition, while V5 (located in the middle temporal gyrus) is responsible for recognizing movements.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Why do unilateral lesions of the primary auditory cortex (Area 41) usually not affect hearing?
back: Because the auditory pathway has a bilateral projection.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the function of Wernicke's area (Area 22) in the dominant hemisphere?
back: It provides language comprehension.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the three multimodal association cortical areas?
back: Limbic (emotion/memory), Posterior (perception/language), and Anterior (planning/concepts) association cortices.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the main functional components of the Basal Ganglia?
back: The striatum (caudate and putamen), globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What three parts make up the caudate nucleus?
back: The head, body, and tail.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What two structures form the lentiform nucleus?
back: The putamen (lateral part) and the globus pallidus (medial part).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which group of arteries ensures the vascularization of most of the caudate nucleus, putamen, and globus pallidus?
back: The Lenticular arteries, which are collaterals of the Middle Cerebral Artery.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the vascular territory of the Anterior Choroidal Artery regarding the corpus striatum?
back: It vascularizes the globus pallidus and the tail of the caudate nucleus via perforating branches.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the vascular territory of the Long Central Artery (Heubner's recurrent artery)?
back: It supplies the head of the caudate nucleus and the anterior half of the putamen.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Into which vein do the striatal veins drain?
back: The internal cerebral vein.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the general flow of information through the corpus striatum?
back: Afferences are projected to the neostriatum, which then sends signals to the paleostriatum, the origin of efferences.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: How do the neostriatum and paleostriatum differ in their regulation of muscle tone?
back: The neostriatum has an inhibitory effect, while the paleostriatum has a facilitating effect on muscle tone.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the three classifications of white matter fibers in the cerebral hemispheres?
back: Association fibres (same hemisphere), Commissural fibres (connect hemispheres), and Projection fibres (cortex to subcortical).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the function of the Cingulum?
back: It is an association fibre that connects the cingulate gyrus to the entorhinal cortex.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which association fasciculus connects the frontal lobe to the temporal lobe?
back: The Uncinate fasciculus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What specific regions does the Arcuate fasciculus connect?
back: It connects the frontal lobe to the temporal lobe.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which part of the corpus callosum connects the orbital portions of the frontal lobes?
back: The rostrum.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which part of the corpus callosum forms the small forceps connecting the medial and lateral sides of the frontal lobes?
back: The genu.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What fibers are contained within the Genu of the internal white capsule?
back: The corticonuclear (or geniculate) fasciculus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Where are the optical radiations located within the internal white capsule?
back: In the retrolenticular segment.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the primary cause and location of the lesion resulting in Hemiballismus?
back: It is caused by lesions of the subthalamic nucleus or the lateral globus pallidus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the etiology of Huntington's disease?
back: It is a genetic defect on chromosome 4 (autosomal dominant) causing degeneration of neurons in the neostriatum.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the underlying mechanism of Sydenham's Chorea?
back: It is an autoimmune response to Group A beta-haemolytic Streptococcus where antibodies attack neostriatum receptors.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What structures form the roof of the body of the lateral ventricle?
back: The corpus callosum.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What structures form the floor of the body of the lateral ventricle?
back: The superior face of the thalamus and the caudate nucleus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What separates the thalamus from the hypothalamus in the lateral wall of the third ventricle?
back: The thalamo-hypothalamic sulcus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which foramen connects the lateral ventricles to the third ventricle?
back: The interventricular foramen of Monro.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the three distinct areas of the bulbar triangle on the floor of the fourth ventricle?
back: The floor features the internal white wing (hypoglossal trigone), the grey wing (vagus trigone), and the external white wing (vestibular area).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What specific cranial nerve nuclei are located within the hypoglossal and vagal trigones?
back: The hypoglossal trigone contains the nucleus of the hypoglossal nerve, while the vagal trigone contains the dorsal nucleus of the vagus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What structures form the roof of the fourth ventricle?
back: The roof consists of the anterior medullary velum (superiorly) and the cerebellar vermis, posterior medullary velum, and tectorial membrane (inferiorly).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What foramina connect the fourth ventricle to the subarachnoid space?
back: The foramen of Magendie (median) and the foramina of Luschka (lateral).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is hydrocephalus and what are its common causes?
back: Hydrocephalus is the accumulation of CSF leading to increased intracranial pressure, caused by malformations like stenosis of the aqueduct or acquired conditions like meningitis and tumors.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the lenticulostriate arteries and from which main artery do they arise?
back: These are penetrating branches that supply the internal capsule and basal ganglia, typically arising from the M1 segment of the Middle Cerebral Artery.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What specific vascular territory is supplied by the Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA)?
back: The ACA supplies the medial aspect of the cerebral hemispheres, including the leg area of the motor cortex and the corpus callosum.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the primary vascular territory of the Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)?
back: The MCA supplies the lateral surface of the hemisphere, including the face and arm areas of the motor cortex and the internal capsule.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What structures are located within the cavernous sinus?
back: The cavernous sinus contains the internal carotid artery and cranial nerves III, IV, V1, V2, and VI.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the clinical symptoms of Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis?
back: Symptoms include fever, headache, periorbital swelling, and ophthalmoplegia, often resulting from facial infections.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the characteristic motor deficits found in Anterior Cerebral Artery syndrome?
back: ACA syndrome typically presents with contralateral hemiparesis that predominantly affects the lower limb (crural).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the characteristic motor deficits found in Middle Cerebral Artery syndrome?
back: MCA syndrome typically presents with contralateral hemiparesis that predominantly affects the face and upper limb (facio-brachial).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the primary visual deficit associated with Posterior Cerebral Artery syndrome?
back: PCA syndrome is characterized by contralateral hemianopsia or quadrantopsia due to infarction of the visual cortex.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the pathway of the second-order neuron in the protopathic tactile (crude touch) system?
back: The second-order neuron originates in the gelatinous substance of the posterior horn, crosses to the opposite side, and ascends to the thalamus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Where does decussation occur for the second-order neuron in the thermal and pain sensory pathway for the trunk, limbs, and neck?
back: The axon decussates into the retro-ependymal grey commissure before ascending in the lateral cord on the opposite side.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: In which nucleus is the second-order neuron of the thermal and pain sensory pathway for the trunk and limbs located?
back: It is located in the nucleus proprius of the posterior horn.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the names of the fasciculi that carry fine touch and conscious proprioception signals in the spinal cord?
back: They are the spino-bulbar fasciculi gracile (located medially) and cuneate (located laterally).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Where does the decussation (sensory decussation) occur in the fine touch sensory pathway (dorsal column-medial lemniscus)?
back: It occurs in the medulla oblongata, where axons from the gracile and cuneate nuclei pass to the opposite side to form the medial lemniscus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which specific retinal fibers decussate at the optic chiasm in the visual pathway?
back: The fibers from the nasal half of the retina pass to the opposite side, while temporal fibers remain ipsilateral.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Where are the second-order neurons of the acoustic pathway located?
back: They are located in the cochlear nuclei (dorsal and ventral) in the pons.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the path of decussation for fibers in the acoustic pathway?
back: Fibers from the dorsal cochlear nucleus form the lateral lemniscus mostly on the opposite side, while ventral fibers decussate at the superior olivary nuclei.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Where is the first-order neuron of the vestibular pathway located?
back: It is located in the Scarpa vestibular ganglion.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: In which sensory ganglia are the first-order neurons of the gustatory pathway located?
back: They are located in the geniculate, inferior glossopharyngeal, and plexiform vagal ganglia.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What percentage of corticospinal tract fibers decussate at the pyramidal decussation?
back: 80% of fibers decussate to form the lateral pyramidal fasciculus, while 20% remain anterior and decussate at the segmental level.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Which specific muscle functions have contralateral corticobulbar projections rather than bilateral?
back: The lower face (facial nerve) and the genioglossus muscle (hypoglossal nerve) are controlled contralaterally.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the first synaptic station in the extrapyramidal (automatic motility) pathway?
back: The first synaptic station is at the level of the neostriatum (caudate and putamen).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the spinal cord origins for the sympathetic nervous system?
back: The centers are located at the thoraco-lumbar level (T1-L2).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the spinal cord origins for the parasympathetic nervous system?
back:
The centers are arranged cranially (in the brainstem) and
sacrally (S2-S4).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the functions of the Auerbach and Meissner plexuses in the enteric nervous system?
back: The Auerbach (myenteric) plexus controls peristalsis, while the Meissner (submucosal) plexus controls gland secretion and local blood flow.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Where is the third-order neuron located in the visual pathway?
back: It is located in the lateral geniculate body of the metathalamus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the names of the fasciculi that carry unconscious proprioception to the cerebellum?
back: They are the posterior spinocerebellar fasciculus and the anterior spinocerebellar fasciculus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Where is the second-order neuron of the gustatory pathway located?
back: It is located in the gustatory nucleus (upper part of the solitary nucleus).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the primary function of the glymphatic system identified by Iliff et al. (2012)?
back: It facilitates the clearance of interstitial solutes, including amyloid β, via the exchange of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and interstitial fluid.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: According to Doya (2000), what are the complementary roles of the basal ganglia and cerebellum?
back: The basal ganglia are crucial for action selection and habit learning, while the cerebellum handles motor coordination and error correction.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the function of Central Pattern Generators (CPGs) found in the spinal cord?
back: They generate rhythmic motor patterns (such as locomotion) autonomously, without the need for continuous descending commands.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: In the context of adult neurogenesis, where do new neurons primarily form in the human brain?
back: Neurogenesis is primarily restricted to the subventricular zone and the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What is the significance of the meningeal lymphatic system described by Dupont et al.?
back: It consists of lymphatic vessels in the meninges that drain cerebrospinal fluid and facilitate immune surveillance of the CNS.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Why is white matter considered critical for brain function, as discussed by Douglas Fields (2008)?
back: White matter contains myelinated axons that connect brain regions, allowing for the rapid transmission of information.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: Do corticospinal projections originate only from the primary motor cortex (M1)?
back: No, significant projections also originate from premotor areas in the frontal lobe.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: How does the number of neurons in the cerebral cortex scale with brain size?
back: Cortical neuron numbers scale in a coordinated manner with cerebellar neuron numbers across mammalian species.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::CEREBRAL HEMISPHERES

front: What are the main components covered in the 'Nervous System – Generalities' chapter?
back: The chapter covers definition, divisions, structure, the neuron, neuroglia (glial cells), the synapse, the reflex, and general nervous pathways.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::VENTRICULAR SYSTEM OF THE BRAIN

front: What key developmental processes are detailed in the 'Nervous System Development' section?
back: This section details neurulation, the formation of brain vesicles, and the development of the spinal cord, brainstem, cerebellum, diencephalon, and cerebral hemispheres.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::VENTRICULAR SYSTEM OF THE BRAIN

front: What specific anatomical and physiological systems are included under 'Cerebro-spinal Meninges'?
back: The section covers the structure of the meninges, cerebrospinal fluid, meningeal lymphatics, and the glymphatic system.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::VENTRICULAR SYSTEM OF THE BRAIN

front: What are the primary topics regarding the 'Spinal Cord' discussed in the text?
back: The text discusses generalities, relations, external configuration, segmentation, vascularization, spinal nerves, medullary reflexes, and spinal cord structure.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::VENTRICULAR SYSTEM OF THE BRAIN

front: What structural elements are analyzed in the 'Brainstem' chapter?
back: The chapter analyzes localization, relations, external configuration, vascularization, internal structure, cranial nerve nuclei, brainstem nuclei, fasciculi, and transverse sections.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::VENTRICULAR SYSTEM OF THE BRAIN

front: What specific components of the Cerebellum are described in its dedicated chapter?
back: The description includes generalities, relations, external configuration, vascularization, structure, connections, and the cerebellum peduncles.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::VENTRICULAR SYSTEM OF THE BRAIN

front: What are the four major subdivisions of the Diencephalon listed in the text?
back: The four major subdivisions are the Thalamus, Epithalamus, Subthalamus, and Hypothalamus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::VENTRICULAR SYSTEM OF THE BRAIN

front: What topics are covered under the section 'Cerebral Hemispheres'?
back: The section covers generalities, configuration, relations, lobes, cerebral cortex structure and divisions, basal ganglia, and white matter.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::VENTRICULAR SYSTEM OF THE BRAIN

front: Which specific ventricles are detailed in the 'Ventricular System of the Brain' chapter?
back: The chapter provides details on the Lateral ventricles, the Third ventricle, and the Fourth ventricle.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::VENTRICULAR SYSTEM OF THE BRAIN

front: What is the primary focus of the review by Sakka, Coll, and Chazal (2011)?
back: The review focuses on the anatomy and physiology of cerebrospinal fluid.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::VENTRICULAR SYSTEM OF THE BRAIN

front: What historical perspective does von Bartheld, Bahney, and Herculano-Houzel (2016) review?
back: They review 150 years of cell counting research to determine the true numbers of neurons and glial cells in the human brain.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::VENTRICULAR SYSTEM OF THE BRAIN

front: According to Rice and Barone Jr. (2000), what concept characterizes early nervous system development?
back: They describe critical periods of vulnerability for the developing nervous system using evidence from humans and animal models.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::VENTRICULAR SYSTEM OF THE BRAIN

front: What percentage of cardiac output does the brain receive, despite being only 2% of body mass?
back: The brain receives 15-20% of blood volume (or 750-800 ml/min), which is permanently adapted to oxygen and glucose consumption.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::BRAIN VASCULARIZATION

front: What are the seven segments of the Internal Carotid Artery (ICA) in order?
back: The segments are C1 cervical, C2 petrous, C3 lacerum, C4 cavernous, C5 clinoid, C6 ophthalmic, and C7 communicating.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::BRAIN VASCULARIZATION

front: What is the origin and endpoint of the Vertebral Artery?
back: It is a branch of the Subclavicular Artery and terminates at the lower edge of the pons where it joins the opposite side to form the basilar trunk.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::BRAIN VASCULARIZATION

front: Which arteries constitute the arterial polygon (Circle of Willis)?
back: It consists of 2 anterior cerebral arteries, the anterior communicating artery, 2 posterior communicating arteries, and 2 posterior cerebral arteries.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::BRAIN VASCULARIZATION

front: What are the key collateral branches of the A1 segment of the Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA)?
back: The A1 segment gives rise to the anteromedial central artery and Heubner’s recurrent artery, which irrigate the caudate nucleus and internal capsule.
