deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::BRAIN VASCULARIZATION

front: What is the primary vascularization territory of the Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)?
back: The MCA supplies most of the lateral side of the cerebral hemispheres (excluding the upper parietal and lower temporal), the internal capsule, and the striated bodies.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::BRAIN VASCULARIZATION

front: From which artery does the Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) originate and what are its P1 and P2 segments?
back: The PCA is the terminal branch of the basilar artery; P1 is the segment before the posterior communicating artery, and P2 surrounds the midbrain.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::BRAIN VASCULARIZATION

front: What is a key anatomical feature of brain veins compared to peripheral veins?
back: Brain veins are avalvular, allowing for two-way blood flow, and they do not follow the course of the arteries.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::BRAIN VASCULARIZATION

front: What are the Trolard and Labbé veins?
back: The superior anastomotic vein (Trolard) connects the superficial middle cerebral vein to the superior sagittal sinus; the inferior anastomotic vein (Labbé) connects it to the transverse sinus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::BRAIN VASCULARIZATION

front: What critical structures pass through the Cavernous Sinus?
back: It contains the carotid siphon of the internal carotid artery and cranial nerves III, IV, VI, and V (V1 and V2).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::BRAIN VASCULARIZATION

front: What distinguishes the motor weakness in Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) syndrome?
back: ACA syndrome causes contralateral hemiparesis that is predominantly crural (leg), affecting the lower limb more than the arm or face.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::BRAIN VASCULARIZATION

front: What are the primary clinical features of Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) syndrome?
back: It features contralateral hemiparesis that is predominantly facio-brachial, hemianopsia, and aphasia (dominant hemisphere) or hemispatial neglect (non-dominant).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::BRAIN VASCULARIZATION

front: What is the main visual symptom of Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) syndrome?
back: The primary symptom is contralateral hemianopsia or quadrantopsia, often accompanied by disorders in color appreciation or cortical blindness.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::BRAIN VASCULARIZATION

front: How does a superficial facial infection lead to Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis?
back: Infection spreads via emissary veins passing through the foramen lacerum or ovale into the pterygoid plexus, which connects to the cavernous sinus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::BRAIN VASCULARIZATION

front: Where does the Straight Sinus drain?
back: The straight sinus is located at the junction of the falx cerebri and tentorium cerebelli and drains into the confluence of sinuses.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::BRAIN VASCULARIZATION

front: Where does the second-order neuron axon cross in the protopathic tactile (crude touch) pathway for the trunk and limbs?
back: It decussates in the pre-endymal grey commissure to ascend in the anterior medullary cord on the opposite side.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::SYNTHESIS OF NERVOUS PATHWAY

front: Where does the decussation occur in the thermal and pain sensory pathway for the trunk and limbs?
back: It decussates in the retro-ependymal grey commissure into the lateral cord on the opposite side.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::SYNTHESIS OF NERVOUS PATHWAY

front: In the fine touch and conscious proprioception pathway, where do the second-order neuron axons decussate?
back: They decussate in the sensory decussation of the medulla oblongata after synapsing in the gracile and cuneate nuclei.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::SYNTHESIS OF NERVOUS PATHWAY

front: What specific fibers decussate at the optical chiasm in the visual pathway?
back: The fibers from the nasal half of the retina pass to the opposite side, while temporal fibers remain ipsilateral.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::SYNTHESIS OF NERVOUS PATHWAY

front: What is the pathway and peduncle used by the posterior spinocerebellar fasciculus?
back: It passes into the lateral cord of the same side, ascends to the medulla, and projects to the paleocerebellum via the inferior cerebellar peduncle.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::SYNTHESIS OF NERVOUS PATHWAY

front: What is the pathway and peduncle used by the anterior spinocerebellar fasciculus?
back: It passes into the lateral cord on the opposite side, ascends to the midbrain, and projects to the paleocerebellum via the superior cerebellar peduncles.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::SYNTHESIS OF NERVOUS PATHWAY

front: Where does decussation occur in the acoustic pathway?
back: It occurs partially at the level of the trapezoidal body and superior olivary nuclei in the pons.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::SYNTHESIS OF NERVOUS PATHWAY

front: Which cranial nerve components are exceptions to the bilateral innervation rule of the cortico-bulbar fasciculus?
back: The part of the facial nerve controlling the lower face muscles and the part of the hypoglossal nerve controlling the genioglossus muscle are primarily contralateral.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::SYNTHESIS OF NERVOUS PATHWAY

front: What are the two main destinations for axons from the second-order neurons in the vestibular pathway?
back: Part of the fibers travel to the archicerebellum via inferior peduncles, while others project to the thalamus and then to the parieto-insular vestibular cortex.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::SYNTHESIS OF NERVOUS PATHWAY

front: What are the first two synaptic stations in the extrapyramidal motor pathways?
back: The first station is the neostriatum (caudate and putamen), followed by the globus pallidus.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::SYNTHESIS OF NERVOUS PATHWAY

front: What are the main mediators for the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems?
back: The sympathetic system primarily uses noradrenaline, while the parasympathetic system uses acetylcholine.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: Where are the central centers located for the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems?
back: Sympathetic centers are located at the thoraco-lumbar level (T1-L2), whereas parasympathetic centers are cranial (brainstem) and sacral (S2-S4).
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: What is the structural characteristic of the autonomic efferent pathway compared to the somatic nervous system?
back: The autonomic efferent system consists of two neurons: a preganglionic neuron in the CNS and a postganglionic neuron in the PNS.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: What is the path of sympathetic preganglionic fibers from the spinal cord to the paravertebral ganglia?
back: Fibers originate in the lateral horns, pass through the anterior root, and travel via the white communicating branch to reach the paravertebral ganglia.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: Which sympathetic ganglia distribute fibers to the head, neck, and heart?
back: The three cervical ganglia (superior, middle, and inferior) distribute fibers via arterial plexuses and cardiac nerves to these regions.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: How is the adrenal medulla unique regarding its innervation by the sympathetic system?
back: It acts as a modified sympathetic ganglion and is innervated directly by preganglionic fibers, stimulating secretion of catecholamines.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: Which cranial nerves and associated ganglia provide parasympathetic innervation to the head?
back: Cranial nerves III, VII, and IX utilize the ciliary, pterygopalatine, submandibular, and otic ganglia.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: What distinguishes the functions of the Auerbach and Meissner plexuses in the enteric nervous system?
back: The Auerbach (myenteric) plexus controls peristalsis, while the Meissner (submucosal) plexus controls gland secretion and local blood flow.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: What are the effects of sympathetic and parasympathetic stimulation on the eye?
back: Sympathetic stimulation causes mydriasis (dilation), while parasympathetic stimulation causes miosis (constriction) and ciliary muscle contraction.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: How do sympathetic and parasympathetic systems affect gastrointestinal motility and sphincters?
back: Sympathetic stimulation decreases motility and contracts sphincters, whereas parasympathetic stimulation increases motility and relaxes sphincters.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: What are the roles of the sympathetic and parasympathetic systems in male sexual function?
back: The sympathetic system is responsible for ejaculation, while the parasympathetic system is responsible for erection.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: Which sympathetic ganglia contribute to the innervation of the abdomino-pelvic viscera?
back: The lumbar ganglia and associated splanchnic nerves distribute fibers to the celiac and mesenteric plexuses.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: What is the pathway of the Vagus nerve (CN X) in the parasympathetic system?
back: Fibers originate from the dorsal nucleus of the vagus and synapse in intramural ganglia located within the walls of thoracic and abdominal organs.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: What is the primary function of Cerebro-spinal Fluid (CSF)?
back: CSF cushions the brain and spinal cord within the subarachnoid space, providing mechanical protection and maintaining homeostasis by removing metabolic waste.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: What is the primary role of the glymphatic system in the CNS?
back: It facilitates the clearance of soluble waste products and metabolic byproducts from the brain via a perivascular network, primarily active during sleep.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: How is the spinal cord segmented in relation to vertebral levels?
back: The spinal cord consists of 31 segments (8 cervical, 12 thoracic, 5 lumbar, 5 sacral, 1 coccygeal), but anatomically ends at the L1-L2 vertebral level in adults.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: What is the defining characteristic of a medullary (spinal) reflex?
back: It is an involuntary motor response mediated entirely within the spinal cord or brainstem, requiring no conscious input from the brain.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: What are the three anatomical divisions of the brainstem?
back: The brainstem is composed of the midbrain, pons, and medulla oblongata.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: What is the primary role of the cerebellum in motor function?
back: The cerebellum coordinates voluntary movement, maintains balance and posture, and contributes to motor learning, rather than initiating movement.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: What is the function of the thalamus within the diencephalon?
back: The thalamus serves as the major relay station for sensory and motor signals on their way to the cerebral cortex.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: What is the main function of the basal ganglia?
back: The basal ganglia regulate the initiation of voluntary movement and help control procedural learning and habit formation.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: Describe the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) through the ventricular system.
back: CSF flows from the lateral ventricles to the third ventricle, through the cerebral aqueduct to the fourth ventricle, and finally exits into the subarachnoid space.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: What is the function of the Circle of Willis?
back: It provides collateral circulation to the brain by connecting the internal carotid and vertebro-basilar systems, ensuring adequate blood flow if one vessel is blocked.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: What is the function of the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway?
back: This ascending pathway transmits fine touch, vibration, and proprioception from the body to the contralateral sensory cortex.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM

front: What is the primary function of the corticospinal tract?
back: It is the major descending motor pathway responsible for voluntary control of skeletal muscles, particularly for fine motor movements.
deck: Anki-AI Crivii Neuroanatomy Umf Book::AUTONOMOUS NERVOUS SYSTEM
